snippet.textDisplay:
Great video. 
Everything makes perfect sense, but I am having a real problem.

I cannot get the text I put into Sublime3+Lua to effect the Corona Simulator in any way.
I put in exactly what you said(and others), and the simulator stays black as night.

I have downloaded everything everyone says to download, but I seem to be having trouble linking Corona to Sublime 3 or Lua.

Sulime and Lua seem to be working perfect as does Corona, they just are not working together.

It will not let me open main.lua by itself, so I have been opening it with Sublimetext.
I am wondering if this is a hint as to what I am doing wrong

I have been trying to get this running for a week now and have watched many videos and read many blogs to no avail

I even deleted everything and tried to start over a couple times..
Any help would be greatly appreciated.
snippet.textOriginal:
Great video. 
Everything makes perfect sense, but I am having a real problem.

I cannot get the text I put into Sublime3+Lua to effect the Corona Simulator in any way.
I put in exactly what you said(and others), and the simulator stays black as night.

I have downloaded everything everyone says to download, but I seem to be having trouble linking Corona to Sublime 3 or Lua.

Sulime and Lua seem to be working perfect as does Corona, they just are not working together.

It will not let me open main.lua by itself, so I have been opening it with Sublimetext.
I am wondering if this is a hint as to what I am doing wrong

I have been trying to get this running for a week now and have watched many videos and read many blogs to no avail

I even deleted everything and tried to start over a couple times..
Any help would be greatly appreciated.

snippet.textDisplay:
All you need is your favorite editor to work with Corona.  I switch between Sublime & ZeroBrane when working on Corona.
I'm also a long-time Unity developer, but will be switching to Lumberyard going forward. Lua is the scripting language used in Lumberyard.
snippet.textOriginal:
All you need is your favorite editor to work with Corona.  I switch between Sublime & ZeroBrane when working on Corona.
I'm also a long-time Unity developer, but will be switching to Lumberyard going forward. Lua is the scripting language used in Lumberyard.

snippet.textDisplay:
Sir, Kindly help me with this to remove the sprite after the sprite being played once. Did in corona and used texture packer for creating sprite sheet. 


local W = display.contentWidth
local H = display.contentHeight

-- -------------------
local background = display.newImageRect( "background.png", W, H )
background.x = display.contentCenterX
background.y = display.contentCenterY

-- ------------------------------------------------------------------------
--Calling balloonburstsprite.lua file
local objectSheet = require("balloonburstsprite")
local myObjectSheet = graphics.newImageSheet("image/balloonburstsprite.png", objectSheet:getSheet())


    local balloonBurst = display.newSprite(myObjectSheet, objectSheet:getSequenceData())
    balloonBurst.x = display.contentCenterX
    balloonBurst.y = display.contentCenterY

--burst balloon
    balloonBurst:setSequence("burst")
    balloonBurst:play()
snippet.textOriginal:
Sir, Kindly help me with this to remove the sprite after the sprite being played once. Did in corona and used texture packer for creating sprite sheet. 


local W = display.contentWidth
local H = display.contentHeight

-- -------------------
local background = display.newImageRect( "background.png", W, H )
background.x = display.contentCenterX
background.y = display.contentCenterY

-- ------------------------------------------------------------------------
--Calling balloonburstsprite.lua file
local objectSheet = require("balloonburstsprite")
local myObjectSheet = graphics.newImageSheet("image/balloonburstsprite.png", objectSheet:getSheet())


    local balloonBurst = display.newSprite(myObjectSheet, objectSheet:getSequenceData())
    balloonBurst.x = display.contentCenterX
    balloonBurst.y = display.contentCenterY

--burst balloon
    balloonBurst:setSequence("burst")
    balloonBurst:play()

snippet.textDisplay: I would suggest using the sprite listener to call a function that either removes the balloon or turns it's alpha to 0: https://docs.coronalabs.com/guide/media/spriteAnimation/index.html
snippet.textOriginal: I would suggest using the sprite listener to call a function that either removes the balloon or turns it's alpha to 0: https://docs.coronalabs.com/guide/media/spriteAnimation/index.html

snippet.textDisplay: Dr. Burton, I've been trying to get an answer to my question maybe you could help. In the game bubble ball by robert nay you can select a different ball color in options. The ball would then be on level 1 to start the game. Would you be able to do a video or write the code I can't find anyone who knows how. Thanks
snippet.textOriginal: Dr. Burton, I've been trying to get an answer to my question maybe you could help. In the game bubble ball by robert nay you can select a different ball color in options. The ball would then be on level 1 to start the game. Would you be able to do a video or write the code I can't find anyone who knows how. Thanks

snippet.textDisplay: @David Dr. Burton would you tell me where my mistake is, options or level 1scene? Thanks
snippet.textOriginal: @David Dr. Burton would you tell me where my mistake is, options or level 1scene? Thanks

snippet.textDisplay: @David Sorry if it was too much code Dr. Burton.
snippet.textOriginal: @David Sorry if it was too much code Dr. Burton.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Brian Burton Dr. Burton I'm going to copy & paste the way I entered the code. 
Starting in the options scene I'm using only a green and blue png ball. 

function scene:create( event )
local sceneGroup = self.view

	local background = display.newImageRect( "background.png", 650, 450 )
	background.x = display.contentCenterX
	background.y = display.contentCenterY
	
physics.start()
physics.pause()
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
_G.myAvatar = ""
local titleText = display.newText( "Select Your Avatar", 250, 101, native.systemFont, 20 )



local greenBall = display.newImageRect( "greenBall.png", 25, 25 ) 
greenBall.avatar = "greenBall.png"
greenBall.x = display.contentCenterX-200
greenBall.y = display.contentCenterY+40
physics.addBody( greenBall, "static", { density=1.0, radius=12 } ) 

local blueBall = display.newImageRect( "blueBall.png", 25, 25 ) 
blueBall.avatar = "blueBall.png" 
blueBall.x = display.contentCenterX
blueBall.y = display.contentCenterY+40
physics.addBody( blueBall, "static", { density=1.0, radius=12 } ) 

local function onObjectTap( event )
			myAvatar = event.target.avatar
			print( event.target.avatar .. " selected")
		end

greenBall:addEventListener( "tap", onObjectTap )
blueBall:addEventListener( "tap", onObjectTap ) 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sceneGroup:insert( greenBall )
sceneGroup:insert( blueBall ) 

end




The rest of your code is on the level1 scene and the error message appears as soon as I tap the level1 button. 

local avatarText = display.newText("Your Avatar is:", 350 750)
local avatar = display.newImage(myAvatar) 
avatar.x = 350
avatar.y = 900

sceneGroup:insert( avatarText )
sceneGroup:insert( avatar )

end

I'll wait to add the error messages.  Thanks
snippet.textOriginal:
@Brian Burton Dr. Burton I'm going to copy & paste the way I entered the code. 
Starting in the options scene I'm using only a green and blue png ball. 

function scene:create( event )
local sceneGroup = self.view

	local background = display.newImageRect( "background.png", 650, 450 )
	background.x = display.contentCenterX
	background.y = display.contentCenterY
	
physics.start()
physics.pause()
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
_G.myAvatar = ""
local titleText = display.newText( "Select Your Avatar", 250, 101, native.systemFont, 20 )



local greenBall = display.newImageRect( "greenBall.png", 25, 25 ) 
greenBall.avatar = "greenBall.png"
greenBall.x = display.contentCenterX-200
greenBall.y = display.contentCenterY+40
physics.addBody( greenBall, "static", { density=1.0, radius=12 } ) 

local blueBall = display.newImageRect( "blueBall.png", 25, 25 ) 
blueBall.avatar = "blueBall.png" 
blueBall.x = display.contentCenterX
blueBall.y = display.contentCenterY+40
physics.addBody( blueBall, "static", { density=1.0, radius=12 } ) 

local function onObjectTap( event )
			myAvatar = event.target.avatar
			print( event.target.avatar .. " selected")
		end

greenBall:addEventListener( "tap", onObjectTap )
blueBall:addEventListener( "tap", onObjectTap ) 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sceneGroup:insert( greenBall )
sceneGroup:insert( blueBall ) 

end




The rest of your code is on the level1 scene and the error message appears as soon as I tap the level1 button. 

local avatarText = display.newText("Your Avatar is:", 350 750)
local avatar = display.newImage(myAvatar) 
avatar.x = 350
avatar.y = 900

sceneGroup:insert( avatarText )

snippet.textDisplay: Hi David.  Yes, I can do that.  The short answer (without a video) is that you store the selected color in a variable, then apply it to the object using object:setFillColor(variable).  You can store the color using rgb values or by name (i.e. 'red', 'grey', 'black', etc)
snippet.textOriginal: Hi David.  Yes, I can do that.  The short answer (without a video) is that you store the selected color in a variable, then apply it to the object using object:setFillColor(variable).  You can store the color using rgb values or by name (i.e. 'red', 'grey', 'black', etc)

snippet.textDisplay: Just set the background to transparent when you first create the image.  If the image is already created, you can use the eraser to clear the background.
snippet.textOriginal: Just set the background to transparent when you first create the image.  If the image is already created, you can use the eraser to clear the background.

snippet.textDisplay: How about the double balloon tap? Is it the same?
snippet.textOriginal: How about the double balloon tap? Is it the same?

snippet.textDisplay: There are several ways that you could implement a double tap.  The easiest would be to add a property to the ballon that tracked the number of taps, then increment that property in the push function.
snippet.textOriginal: There are several ways that you could implement a double tap.  The easiest would be to add a property to the ballon that tracked the number of taps, then increment that property in the push function.

snippet.textDisplay: Azemoth Otse there are several ways.  The easiest is to make it invisible by changing the alpha property to 0.  You can also set the ballon to nil, but that will completely remove it from the game.

snippet.textDisplay:
Yes, you can write the full app on your pc and publish from your friends Mac.
Corona has very detailed procedures on their website on the publishing process.  
Apple changes the procedures on a regular basis, but Corona Labs does a great job of keeping the process updated.
snippet.textOriginal:
Yes, you can write the full app on your pc and publish from your friends Mac.
Corona has very detailed procedures on their website on the publishing process.  
Apple changes the procedures on a regular basis, but Corona Labs does a great job of keeping the process updated.

snippet.textDisplay: Brian Burton so what if I make this Complete app on my Windows machine and then publish it through my friends mac I think I will just need an apple account would you explain what Is the procedure for publishing your app
snippet.textOriginal: Brian Burton so what if I make this Complete app on my Windows machine and then publish it through my friends mac I think I will just need an apple account would you explain what Is the procedure for publishing your app

snippet.textDisplay: It is an Apple requirement that iOS apps be published from a Mac.  You can fully build the app on a PC, but the final publish must be done from a Mac to be in compliance with Apple's contract that you sign.
snippet.textOriginal: It is an Apple requirement that iOS apps be published from a Mac.  You can fully build the app on a PC, but the final publish must be done from a Mac to be in compliance with Apple's contract that you sign.

snippet.textOriginal: Brian Burton can we make ios app from a Windows pc using corona or do we need a mac like x codes

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi Alan,
Android studio is a nice tool, but I can develop for iOS, Android, Mac, Windows, Ouya, etc with Corona much faster and easier, and at zero cost!
I liked Corona so much, that I started using it to teach my mobile app classes and eventually wrote a textbook for use with Corona.
snippet.textOriginal:
Hi Alan,

I liked Corona so much, that I started using it to teach my mobile app classes and eventually wrote a textbook for use with Corona.

snippet.textDisplay: i dont think corona can beat unity
snippet.textOriginal: i dont think corona can beat unity

snippet.textDisplay:
Yes, you can use 3D models in 2D games in Unity, but at what cost?  Development of 3D models compared to sprite sheets or 2D graphics is significantly higher in cost and time.
And yes, the ux/ui in Unity is nice, but not any better than Corona.  I would say they are tied in that regard.
As for developer community, while Unity has a large community, in my experience the Corona community is much more helpful.
snippet.textOriginal:
Yes, you can use 3D models in 2D games in Unity, but at what cost?  Development of 3D models compared to sprite sheets or 2D graphics is significantly higher in cost and time.
And yes, the ux/ui in Unity is nice, but not any better than Corona.  I would say they are tied in that regard.
As for developer community, while Unity has a large community, in my experience the Corona community is much more helpful.

snippet.textDisplay: Unity is good for 2d also coz you can merge 3D models in 2d space also unity has a good ux/ui and has a great developer community
snippet.textOriginal: Unity is good for 2d also coz you can merge 3D models in 2d space also unity has a good ux/ui and has a great developer community

snippet.textDisplay:
I think you are trying to compare apples to oranges.  It all depends on the needs.  If you are developing a 3D game, no question, Unity or Lumberyard (I would choose Lumberyard) are the way to go.  
If you need to make an app or 2D game, Corona wins easily:
Price - Enterprise and regular Corona are FREE, Unity - personal is free, but everything else costs (a lot)
Community - While Unity has a larger community, I have found the Corona community to be much more helpful
Development Time - Corona is much faster to develop in than Unity
Flexibility - Corona can be used to develop apps, utilities, or games
snippet.textOriginal:
I think you are trying to compare apples to oranges.  It all depends on the needs.  If you are developing a 3D game, no question, Unity or Lumberyard (I would choose Lumberyard) are the way to go.  
If you need to make an app or 2D game, Corona wins easily:
Price - Enterprise and regular Corona are FREE, Unity - personal is free, but everything else costs (a lot)
Community - While Unity has a larger community, I have found the Corona community to be much more helpful
Development Time - Corona is much faster to develop in than Unity
Flexibility - Corona can be used to develop apps, utilities, or games
